Legal_Issue: Whether the Trade-marks Opposition Board erred in rejecting Procter & Gamble's opposition
Procedural_Stage: Appeal from Board decision to Federal Court
Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient proof that others used the same stripe pattern; no clear intent or function tied solely to decoration
Decision_Outcome: Board's decision rejecting the opposition is upheld
Burden_of_Proof: On Procter & Gamble to show grounds for opposition
Legal_Rule: Trademarks must be distinctive, not primarily functional, and capable of distinguishing goods; Section 30 requires intent to use and belief in entitlement to registration
Grounds_for_Claim: Functionality, lack of distinctiveness, ornamental design
Outcome_on_Merits: Opposition failed; Colgate's application remains valid
Decision_Maker: Trade-marks Opposition Board, reviewed by Federal Court
Key_Evidence_Considered: Use of striped design, functionality claims, distinctiveness, prior usage patterns
Applicant_Challenge: Procter & Gamble opposed Colgate's trademark application
Defendant_Response: Colgate maintained its design was registrable and non-functional
Resolution_Mechanism: Administrative opposition followed by judicial review
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Primarily functional design, lack of distinctiveness
Outcome_of_Review: No material new evidence; original decision upheld
